prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal is to detect both spectral line and continuum emissions, so we are using spectral windows with widths of 1.875 GHz. The two spectral windows covering the H40alpha and H42alpha lines are set to fdm mode with spectral averaging of 2 to reduce the data rates without significantly altering the effective spectral resolution. The other two spectral windows, which cover continuum emission, will be observed in tdm mode. With this configuration, the total data rates are ~6.5 MB/s. To avoid having the H40alpha line fall at the edge of a spectral window, the higher-frequency windows overlap each other by 0.375 GHz, or ~20% of the total spectral window width.

The focus of this proposal is on the detection of recombination line emission from the central starburst, so we have opted to use a low angular resolution observing mode of 3 arcsec to avoid resolving out structure. Based on an inspection of Spitzer 5.7-24 micron images, we anticipate that most of the emission will come from a compact, unresolved central source and that most other emission should be from structures with angular sizes <25 arcsec.

Our sensitivity goal is based on detecting the H40alpha and H42alpha line emission in 24 km/s channels at the 10 sigma level. Based on an inspection of Spitzer 5.7-24 micron images, we anticipate that ~70% of the total H40alpha line emission may originate from a <2 arcsec source. The estimated 24 micron emission from this source is 1.30 Jy. Using the conversions from 24 micron flux to star formation rate from Rieke et al. (2009, ApJ, 692, 556) and the conversion from star formation rate to H40alpha line flux from Bendo et al. (2015, arXiv:1504.02142; see also Scoville & Murchikova, 2013, ApJ, 779, 75), we estimate the H40alpha line flux for this region is 0.076 Jy km/s. If the spectral line emission is produced purely by star formation, we anticipate that the spectral line may be as broad as 200 km/s; see, for example, the Bendo et al. (2015, arXiv:1504.02142) results for NGC 253. We want to measure the emission in 24 km/s resolution elements so that we can examine velocity substructure in the line profiles, and we need to detect the emission at the 10 sigma level. As a result, we have set our target rms sensitivity to 0.90 mJy integrated over 24 km/s at a rest frequency of 99.02 GHz. The flux for the H42alpha line should be similar, and the line should be detected at a similar sensitivity level. The continuum, which will be integrated over a ~7 GHz band width, should be detected at a higher S/N level.
(Note that the OT has a software issue where it does not allow us to change the representative frequency. The sensitivity goal is for a rest frequency of 99.02 GHz and not the centre of baseband 4.)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to study star formation in a volume-limited set of 6 starburst-dominated nearby luminous infrared galaxies (LIRGs) using the H40alpha and H42alpha recombination lines as well as free-free emission at 86.0-99.4 GHz, which directly traces the photoionized gas associated with young stars (unlike infrared and radio synchrotron emission) without suffering from dust attenuation (which affects ultraviolet, optical, and near-infrared star formation tracers). Our primary goal is to use the ALMA data to accurately measure star formation rates within these galaxies, which we can then use to calibrate other star formation tracers, particularly infrared emission, in these extreme systems. Our other goals include identifying the relative contributions of free-free and dust emission to this frequency band, measuring dust attenuation, and searchig for any highly obscured active galactic nuclei. The overall results will have implications for modelling the stellar evolution and radiative transfer in LIRGs as well as modelling star formation over the history of the Universe.
